author: jianyunt
body:
Steps to reproduce
------------------
``` PowerShell
class Environment 
{
    Environment()
    {
    } 
    Environment([string]$name)
    { #do something    }
    [object] FooBar()
    {
        return get-process powershell
    }
 }
```
Save the above as temp.psm1 and create  its corresponding temp.psd1
Also See the entire discussion here https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/3251 

I expect the following cases should work.
``` PowerShell
1) using module .\temp.psm1  -- works. Good.

2) using module .\temp.pds1   --- does not work

At line:1 char:1
+ using module .\temp.pds1
+ ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Could not find the module '.\temp.pds1'.
    + CategoryInfo          : ParserError: (:) [], ParentContainsErrorRecordException
    + FullyQualifiedErrorId : ModuleNotFoundDuringParse

3) $a="c:\test\temp.psm1"
    using module $a   ------------ does not work. 

At line:1 char:1
+ using module $a
+ ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
'$a' is not a valid value for using name.
    + CategoryInfo          : ParserError: (:) [], ParentContainsErrorRecordException
    + FullyQualifiedErrorId : InvalidValueForUsingItemName
```
 If the above case 3 worked, we could do something like below:
    $a=Get-module temp
     using Moduel $a.Path

----------------

```powershell
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      6.0.0-alpha
GitCommitId                    v6.0.0-alpha.16-35-g669a34a27bd51756e49f50dc627cd4a89fd8244a

PSEdition                      Core
CLRVersion

WSManStackVersion              3.0
BuildVersion                   3.0.0.0
```

comments.body: You have a typo on your second example.  Should be `.psd1`

comments.author: lzybkr
comments.body:
You have a typo, pds1 is not a valid module extension.

Using module is a parse time construct and should not support expressions.

title: Using module should work with .psd1
